MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A 33 Weeks multigravida woman presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, and proteinuria - 3+. The next step of management would be?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 33 weeks pregnant woman with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, and proteinuria 3+ indicates severe preeclampsia. The next step of management would be iv administration of MgSO4 for the prevention of seizures. 

Preeclampsia can be classified as severe if any of the following are present: 

  • BP ≥160/110
  • Headache
  • Visual disturbance
  • Upper abdominal pain
  • Elevated creatinine, oliguria
  • Thrombocytopenia (<1,00,000 cells per mm3)
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Marked elevation in serum transaminases
  • Fetal growth restriction

Dexamethasone (option B) is also given in severe preeclampsia <34 weeks for fetal lung maturity. But the administration of MgSO4 before corticosteroids would be the next best step for the prevention of seizures. 

Immediate delivery (options A and C) is not indicated in this case as the patient doesn't have any contraindication for conservative management. Conservative management is contraindicated in the following cases:

  • Persistent symptoms, refractory to treatment or severe hypertension
  • Eclampsia, pulmonary edema, HELLP syndrome
  • Significant renal dysfunction or coagulopathy
  • Placental abruption
  • Nonreassuring fetal status
  • Fetal demise
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Stroke, myocardial infarction

MgSO4 regimens for management of eclampsia and severe preeclampsia:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibal) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2g/h IV infusion

Magnesium sulfate is discontinued either 24 hours after delivery or 24 hours after the onset of convulsions (whichever is later).

questions.text: You have ordered a patch test for an 8-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis. After the application of the patch, when should you ask him to return for removal?
questions.solution:
In patch testing, the patch is removed after 48 hours to examine the site of reaction.

Patch testing is a test to detect sensitivity to a specific allergen. A battery of suspected allergens is applied to the patient’s back under occlusive dressings or patches. It is allowed to remain in contact with the skin for 48 hours.

  • 48 hours:  Patch removal for initial reading to detect delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • 72-96 hours: Final reading done for confirmation. 

Note: Since the question is regarding the timing of patch removal and not regarding the final diagnosis, 48 hours is the answer.

questions.text: A  patient says that he feels that there is something wrong with him mentally and it is because of the summer season. How much would he score on the insight scale?
questions.solution:
The patient would score 3, as he is aware of being sick but has attributed it to external factors.

Insight is rated on a 5 point scale:

  1. Complete denial of illness.
  2. Slight awareness of being sick and needing help but denying it at the same time.
  3. Awareness of being sick, but is attributed to physical or external factors.
  4. Intellectual insight - awareness of being ill, and that the symptoms are due to own particular irrational feelings and thoughts.
  5. Emotional insight - the highest level of insight. Intellectual insight with making significant changes in future behavior.

Loss of insight is seen in schizophrenia, mania, delusional disorders, etc.

questions.text: Pacemaker generating the rhythm for breathing is ________

choices.text: Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla

questions.solution:
Pre-Botzinger complex generates the rhythm for automated breathing.

  • These are also known as pacemaker cells located in the medulla.
  • These are the first set of neurons that initiate inspiration.
  • These neurons discharge rhythmically, and they produce rhythmic discharges in the phrenic motor neurons.

Breathing is under the control of both the following:

  • Voluntary control: Located in the cerebral cortex (via corticospinal tract)
  • Automatic control: Driven by pacemaker cells in the medulla (Pre-Botzinger complex). These activate motor neurons via cervical (Phrenic nerve innervating diaphragm) and thoracic spinal cord (external intercostal muscle).

There is a reciprocal innervation to expiratory and inspiratory muscles in that motor neurons supplying expiratory muscles are inactive when motor neurons supplying inspiratory muscles are active, and vice versa.

 

Inspiration
Initiation Pre-Botzinger complex (Pacemaker cells) in Medulla
Maintenance Apneustic center in lower Pons stimulates Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla
Termination  Apneustic center inhibited by Vagus and Pneumotaxic center

Regulation of expiration: During quiet breathing, expiration is a passive process; there is no firing of neurons. Ventral respiratory group of neurons are involved in forceful expiration like during exercise.

Mnemonic DIVE: Dorsal respiratory group for Inspiration and Ventral respiratory group for Expiration.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

Respiratory center component

Primary function

Pre-Bőtzinger complex

Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Respiratory rhythm generator (inspiratory ramp signal)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Overdrive mechanism

Pneumotaxic centre

Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal

Apneustic centre

Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration

Vagi

Inhibits inspiratory discharge

questions.text:
Match the following anesthetic agents with respect to their side effects.
Column-A Column-B
1. Propofol a. Rigid chest syndrome
2. Fentanyl b. Pulmonary vasoconstriction
3. Midazolam c. Egg allergy
4. Nitrous oxide d. Hypotension
  e. Dissociative Anesthesia
  f. Adrenal insufficiency
questions.solution:
The correct match of the anaesthetic agents and their side effects is as follows:

  • Propofol is associated with risk of egg allergy as the drug being lipid-soluble, is usually combined with soybean oil, glycerol, and egg phospholipid.
  • Fentanyl can cause severe rigidity of the chest muscles, a condition is commonly known as wooden or rigid chest syndrome.
  • Midazolam causes vasodilatation may lead to hypotension.
  • Nitrous oxide may cause pulmonary vasoconstriction.

questions.text:
Arrange the following blisters in order from superficial to deep.
  1. Pemphigus vulgaris
  2. Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica
  3. Linear IgA
  4. Bullous pemphigoid
questions.solution:
From superficial to deep the order of blisters is as follows:

  1. Pemphigus Vulgaris - 4. Bullous pemphigoid - 3.Linear IgA - 2.Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica.

Pemphigus Vulgaris: 

  • Suprabasal blister which occurs due to the presence of autoantibodies against Desmoglein 1 and 3.
  • The most common type of pemphigus
  • Histology shows characteristic row of tombstone appearance, as the suprabasal acantholytic blister leaves behind a single layer of intact basal cells.
  • Direct immunofluorescence: A fish net-like pattern of intercellular IgG deposits.

Bullous pemphigoid:

  • It usually affects elders (60-80 years).
  • Tense subepidermal blisters will be present.
  • There is no mucosal involvement (unlike Pemphigus Vulgaris)
  • Immunofluorescence: Linear IgG deposits are present along the basement membrane (subepidermal) targeted against BPAg2>BPAg1

 Linear IgA:

  • Linear IgA deposits are also seen along the basement membrane zone (subepidermal) targeted against BPAg-2>BPAg-1.
  • In addition, there is also the involvement of BPAg and laminin.

 Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica is due to the involvement of collagen-7.

  • The blister is present between lamina densa and dermis.

 

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

  • Other disorders
    • Infections - VZV, HSV, Bullous impetigo, SSSS
    • Metabolic - Porphyria, Diabetes, Hemodialysis
    • Drug eruptions - Fixed drug eruption, Steven Johnson Syndrome, Erythema Multiforme

questions.text: All lung carcinomas for diagnosis requires CECT thorax but MRI is useful in which of the following:
questions.solution:
MRI is useful in Pancoast tumor because of the associated soft tissue infiltration, extent of which can be best visualised using an MRI

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction,
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis).

questions.text: Deep y descent in JVP is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
The y-descent in jugular venous pulse (JVP) corresponds to the fall in right atrial pressure after the tricuspid valve opening in the early diastolic phase of the right ventricle. Y-descent is attenuated or absent in cardiac tamponade because of resistance to ventricular filling in the early diastole.

Other options:

Options B and C: Restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis can have deep y descent due to rapid filling of the right ventricle during early diastole.

Option D: In patients with tricuspid regurgitation, increased blood flow to the right atria through the incompetent tricuspid valve during ventricular systole results in a prominent v wave. When the tricuspid valve opens during ventricular diastole, this increased blood in the right atria enters rapidly into the right ventricle during early diastole resulting in deep y-descent.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: All of the following are features of SIRS except:
questions.solution:
Respiratory Rate > 20/minute or (Not and) PaCO2 < 32 mmHg (Not <35 mmHg) would be a feature of SIRS (Systemic inflammatory response syndrome).

Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is an exaggerated defense response of the body to a noxious stressor (infection, trauma, surgery, acute inflammation, ischemia, or reperfusion) to localize and then eliminate the endogenous or exogenous source of the insult.

SIRS is diagnosed when any two of the following are present:

  • Hyperthermia (>38 Degree Celsius) or Hypothermia (<36 Degree Celsius)
  • Tachypnoea (>20/min) or PaCO2 < 32 mmHg
  • Tachycardia (>90/min) 
  • White cell count >12 x 109/liter or <4 x 109/liter or >10% Band forms

 Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with skin-colored umbilicated papules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
The given microscopic image shows large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is about 300 nm in size, the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans

Tzanck smear shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30–35 μm).

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules (shown below). A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

questions.text: Chimeric DNA is associated with:
questions.solution:
Chimeric DNA is associated with organ transplantation, especially bone-marrow transplantation. 

In organ transplantation, chimeric DNA refers to the mixture of donor and recipient genetic material that occurs when donor cells begin functioning within the recipient's body. It is used for long-term monitoring of bone marrow transplant recipients. Detecting changes in the levels of donor-derived cells can provide early warning signs of graft failure, rejection, or relapse of underlying disease. 

Note: The practical applications of recombinant DNA technology include:

  • Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
  • Producing proteins such as:
    • Interferons, tPA (tissue plasminogen activator)
    • Insulin, growth hormone
    • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  • Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)
  • Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  • Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: True/ False regarding the carotid sheath:
questions.solution:
The only true statement is that the carotid sheath is formed by an investing layer of deep fascia(statement 2).

The ansa cervicalis lies on the anterior, not the posterior, surface of the carotid sheath. Hence the given statement is false.

The carotid sheath is contributed to by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia, the prevertebral fascia, and the pretracheal fascia.  Hence the given statement is true. But note that this is a controversial question as Grays Anatomy 41st edition states that "There is disagreement about whether the carotid sheath is formed by all three layers of the deep cervical fascia, or exclusively by the deep or the superficial layer, or even that it lacks a demonstrable fascial ensheathment"

The contents of the carotid triangle

  1. Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery
  2. Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal and occipital artery
  3. Internal jugular vein
  4. Vagus nerve
  5. Hypoglossal nerve
  6. Spinal part of the accessory Nerve (not cranial)
  7. Sympathetic chain

The vagus continues in the carotid sheath whilst the other nerves exit the carotid sheath after being initially enclosed by it. 

The vagus (not sympathetic chain) lies in between Internal carotid arteries and internal jugular vein. Hence the given statement is false

The common carotid artery divides at the level of the superior border of the thyroid cartilage. Hence the given statement is false.

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution:
Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system.

Causes of prolonged PT:

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists
  • Liver disease - obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare)

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway.

Causes of prolonged APTT:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants
  • A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII
  • Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs
  • Vitamin K deficiency

Related Pearl: Coagulation Pathways and its Abnormalities

Test results Inherited causes Acquired causes

Prolonged PT 

Evaluates extrinsic pathway factors

Normal PT: 11-13 seconds

Mild vitamin K deficiency

Liver disease

Warfarin

Prolonged aPTT

Evaluates intrinsic pathway factors

Normal aPTT: 25-35 seconds

Factor XII, prekallikrein, or HMW kininogen deficiency

von Willebrand disease

questions.text:
Match the following tests and poisons:
Column-A Column-B
1. Marsh test a. Opium
2. Silver nitrate paper test b. Aluminium phosphide
3. Cavett test c. Cyanide
4. Marqui's test d. Alcohol
  e. Arsenic
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:
  1. Marsh test - Arsenic
  2. Silver nitrate paper test - Aluminium phosphide
  3. Cavett test - Alcohol
  4. Marqui’s test - Opium
 
  1. Marsh test was used to detect arsenic poisoning. Another test which was used to detect arsenic poisoning was Reinsch’s test. However, both these tests are currently obsolete. The diagnostic methods which are currently being used to detect arsenic poisoning include atomic absorption spectroscopy, and 24-hour urine test (excretion of more than 100 μg of arsenic is positive).
 
  1. Silver nitrate paper test: This test used to detect aluminium phosphide poisoning. 
    • Aluminium phosphide (ALP)is used as a pesticide, insecticide, and rodenticide.
    • When ALP comes in contact with moisture, it releases an active component called phosphine.
    • When the silver nitrate impregnated filter paper, comes in contact with phosphine the paper turns black in colour.
    • The test is done in two methods:
    • a. Gastric aspirate: 5 mL of gastric aspirate and 15 mL of water are put in a flask and the mouth of the flask is covered with silver nitrate impregnated filter paper. The flask is heated at 50°C for 15 to 20 minutes. If the filter paper turns black, it indicates the presence of phosphine.
    • b. Breath: The patient is asked to breathe in and out through a face mask which is impregnated with silver nitrate. If the face mask turns black, it indicates the presence of phosphine. The breath test is positive only if the patient ingests more than 6 grams of aluminium phosphide.
 
  1. Cavett test: It is a micro method used for determining blood alcohol. Kozelka and Hine test is the macro method. These tests are based on the principle that the potassium bichromate is reduced in the presence of alcohol. However, for medico-legal purposes, gas chromatography test is the most desirable test.
 
  1. Marqui’s test: The test is used to detect opium poisoning. A drop of the mixture consisting of 3mL of concentrated sulphuric acid and 3 drops of formalin is added to a fragment of the suspected residue. A positive test is indicated if the residue turns to purple-red colour which gradually changes to violet and finally to blue.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not supplied by the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the oculomotor nerve and it does not supply the superior oblique muscle. Superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve.

 All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

questions.text:
SGLT-2 inhibitors are recently used for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following are the rare but serious side effects?

a. Ketoacidosis

b. Fournier gangrene

c. Urosepsis

d. Angioedema

choices.text: All four (a, b, c, and d) are correct
a, b and c are correct

questions.solution:
All of the above options are serious complications of SGLT-2 inhibitors.
 
  • Sodium-glucose transporter-2(SGLT-2)inhibitors have been recently approved for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.  
  • SGLT-2 transporter is present in the proximal tubule and is responsible for the reabsorption of the glucose. The glucose is transported against its concentration gradient coupled with the transport of sodium(cotransport). About 80-90%of the glucose reabsorption occurs through these transporters.
  • Drugs that block the SGLT-2, prevents the reabsorption of the glucose from the tubular lumen. causing glycosuria and reducing the blood glucose concentration.
  • The SGLT-2 inhibitors currently available are canagliflozin, dapagliflozin and empagliflozin.
 
The adverse effects include:
  • Lower limb amputations
  • Hypotension
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Acute kidney injury
  • Urosepsis and pyelonephritis
  • Increased risk of hypoglycemia when combined with Insulin and Insulin Secretagogues
  • Necrotizing Fasciitis of the Perineum(Fournier's Gangrene)
  • Genital Mycotic Infections
  • Hypersensitivity Reactions includine angioedema and anaphylaxis
  • Bone Fracture
  • Increase in Low-Density Lipoprotein(LDL-C)

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures is a branch of the internal carotid artery?
questions.solution:
The structure marked 1 is the anterior ethmoidal artery, which is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

2 – Sphenopalatine artery

3 – Greater palatine artery

4 – Superior labial artery

2, 3 and 4 are derived from branches of the external carotid artery.

The nasal septum is supplied by branches of both internal and external carotid arteries.

Related Pearl: Internal carotid artery branches

Part
Course
 Branches
Cervical part
Originates from the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. It has a dilation at the lower end which is known as carotid sinus. It ascends in front of the transverse process of the upper three cervical vertebrae.
 No branches given
Petrous part
Passes through the carotid canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone
  • Caroticotympanic branch
  • Artery to the pterygoid canal
Cavernous part
Runs in the cavernous sinus
  • Branch to the trigeminal ganglion
  • Meningeal branch
  • Branch to the cavernous sinus
  • Hypophyseal branches
Cerebral part/ Supracavernal part
Enters subarachnoid space by piercing arachnoid mater and divides into the anterior and middle cerebral arteries.
  • Ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior choroidal artery
  • Posterior communicating artery

The petrous, cavernous and intracranial parts of the internal carotid artery are called the carotid siphon because of its sigmoid course.

questions.text:
Assertion: Range of shot can be determined by the spread of pellets.
Reason: Shotgun cartridge contain pellets.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are correct and reason is correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct but reason is not a correct explanation of assertion
Both Assertion and reason are wrong

questions.solution:
Both assertion and reason are independently true. But, the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion.

questions.text: The given pattern of EEG is found in:
questions.solution:
Periodic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes are seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

It is a spongiform encephalopathy that is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar/visual disturbances. Caused by Prions. It is fatal and death occurs usually within a year or less from the onset.

EEG shows characteristic periodic sharp wave complexes (bi/triphasic). CSF assay is positive for 14-3-3 protein.

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

  1. Sporadic (sCJD): Accounts for 85-90% of cases
    • MRI shows cortical ribbon sign
  2. Variant (vCJD): mad cow disease, Kuru
    • MRI shows hockey stick sign
  3. Familial (fCJD): 10% of cases (these individuals carry a PRPc mutation)
  4. Iatrogenic

Option A: Hepatic encephalopathy will show a triphasic wave pattern (negative-positive-negative wave). They are also seen in Hashimoto encephalopathy and CO2 narcosis.

Option C: GTCS (generalized tonic clonic seizures)will show high voltage bursts & high voltage spikes present in all the leads.

Option D: HSV encephalitis usually affects one side temporal lobe showing a characteristic periodic lateralised epiletptiform discharge.

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for:
questions.solution:
Transmission assessment survey is carried out for filariasis.

Mass Drug Administration is used to reduce infection in the community to levels below a threshold at which mosquitoes are unable to continue spreading the parasites from person to person and thus new infections are prevented.

The transmission assessment survey (TAS) is used to determine when infections have been reduced below target thresholds and Mass Drug Administration can stop. Once MDA has stopped, TAS is used as a surveillance tool to determine that infection levels are sustained below target thresholds.

questions.text: Topical steroids are most effective in:
questions.solution:
Topical steroids are the drug of choice in the treatment of eczematous dermatitis.

Other options:

  • Steroids cause atrophy and hence is contraindicated in patients with dermal atrophy.
  • Herpes infection is associated with immunosuppression so steroids are not useful.
  • Routine steroid use not recommended in rosea as it can worsen the condition.

questions.text: True about the definition of Postural Hypotension:

choices.text: Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing
Decrease in Diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing

questions.solution:
Orthostatic hypotension or postural hypotension is defined as a sustained drop in systolic BP of ≥20 mmHg or diastolic BP of ≥10 mmHg after 3 min of standing.

It can manifest as lightheadedness/dizziness, weakness or tiredness, difficulty thinking/concentrating, blurred vision, and anxiety.

In non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension such as hypovolemia, the drop in the blood pressure is accompanied by a compensatory increase in heart rate of >15 beats/min. In neurogenic causes, there is aggravation or precipitation of orthostatic hypotension by autonomic stressors like a meal, hot bath, or exercise.

Non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension include

  • Cardiac pump failure - myocardial infarction, myocarditis, aortic stenosis
  • Hypovolemia - dehydration, diarrhea, hemorrhage
  • Metabolic - adrenocortical insufficiency, pheochromocytoma
  • Venous pooling - sepsis, prolonged standing, or recumbency
  • Medications - alpha-blockers, diuretics, phenothiazines, tricyclic antidepressants

Treatment includes removing reversible causes like drugs causing hypotension. Non-pharmacological interventions include patient education regarding staged moves from supine to upright, raising the head of the bed, and increasing dietary fluid and salt. If these fail, drugs like fludrocortisone and midodrine can be given.

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent?
questions.solution: Sporothrix schenckii is a subcutaneous fungal agent. The other three mentioned are systemic mycoses.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding depersonalization disorder?

choices.text: More common after life threatening trauma
Seen in seizure and migraine patients
Mean age at onset is 25 years

questions.solution:
Depersonalization is common after a life-threatening trauma.
 
The DSM-V defines depersonalisation as experiences of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer with respect to one’s thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions (e.g., perceptual alterations, distorted sense of time, unreal or absent self, emotional and/ or physical numbing).
 
Another term called derealization refers to the experiences of unreality or detachment with respect to the surroundings.
 
The DSM-V diagnostic criteria for depersonalization/derealization disorder is as follows:
  1. The presence of persistent or recurrent experiences of depersonalization, derealization, or both.
  2. Intact reality testing, during the episodes.
  3. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
  4. The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance(e.g., a drug of abuse, medication) or another medical condition(e.g., seizures). (option b)
  5. The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as schizophrenia, panic disorder, major depressive disorder, acute stress disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, or another dissociative disorder.
 
Characteristic features of depersonalization/derealization disorder:
  • The condition commonly occurs after a life-threatening trauma.
  • There is no gender preponderance. Male:Female ratio is 1:1 (option c).
  • Mean age at onset is 16 years (option d).
  • The condition is commonly associated with symptoms such as an altered sense of time, difficulty in remembering past memories, anxiety and depression.

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constants:
questions.solution:
The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is expressed as Kcat/Km.

Kcat is the rate constant, which is the limiting rate of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction at saturation. It is given by Vmax divided by number of active sites of the enzyme. Km is the Michaelis-Menten constant, which is defined as the substrate concentration at which the initial velocity(Vi) is half the maximum velocity (Vmax/2).

For some enzymes, when a substrate (S) binds to the active site of the enzyme (E), and forms an enzyme-substrate complex (ES), the product is instantaneously formed. For such enzymes, the reaction of E+S→ES becomes the rate-limiting step. Its rate is determined on the rate of diffusion of the molecules in a solution. Hence, these enzymes are called diffusion-limited or catalytically perfect.

Examples of the catalytically perfect enzymes, where the catalytic efficiency reaches the diffusion limit of 108-109 M−1s−1:

  • Triosephosphate isomerase
  • Carbonic anhydrase
  • Acetylcholinesterase
  • Adenosine deaminase

questions.text:
Match the antimicrobial drugs preferred for the organism:
Antimicrobial drug Organism
1. Praziquantel a. A. lumbricoides
2. Mebendazole b. Tape worm
3. Nitazoxanide c. Filariasis
4. DEC d. Leishmaniasis
  e. Giardiasis
  f. Onchocerca volvulus
questions.solution:
The correct match of the given drugs and the organism against which it is preferred is as follows:
 
  1. Praziquantel - Tapeworm
  2. Mebendazole - A. lumbricoides
  3. Nitazoxanide - Giardiasis
  4. DEC(Diethylcarbamazine)- Filariasis
 
  1. Praziquantel: It is the drug of choice for the treatment of schistosome infections and most of the trematode and cestode (tapeworm infections).
  2. Mebendazole: It is the drug of choice in the treatment of ascariasis, trichuriasis, trichinosis, hookworm and pinworm infections.
  3. Nitazoxanide: It has been recently approved for the treatment against Giardia lamblia and Cryptosporidium parvum. However, it is not the drug of choice for these organisms. The drug of choice for giardiasis is metronidazole or tinidazole. Whereas, the drug of choice for cryptosporidium species is paromomycin.
  4. Diethylcarbamazine(DEC): It is the drug of choice for the treatment of filariasis, loiasis, and tropical eosinophilia.

questions.text:
The correct sequence of maturation of sperms in spermatogenesis
  1. Spermatozoa
  2. Spermatogonia
  3. Spermatocytes
  4. Spermatid
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is Spermatogonia -> Spermatocytes -> Spermatid -> Spermatozoa

Spermatogenesis begins at adolescence and the complete process takes about 74 days and about 300 million sperms are produced daily.

questions.text:
Match the following:
Column-A Column-B
1. Howell jolly bodies a. Ig inclusions
2. Dohle bodies b. Azurophilic granules
3. Flame cells c. Nuclear material remnants
4. Auer rod cells d. Remnants of ER
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:
  1. Howell-Jolly bodies - c. Nuclear material remnants
  2. Dohle bodies - d. Remnants of ER
  3. Flame cells - a. Ig inclusions
  4. Auer rods - b. Azurophilic granules
 
 
1. Howell-Jolly bodies are the nuclear remnants present in the RBCs. They appear as dense blue colored circular inclusions. They are usually seen in patients lacking normal spleen function (asplenia).

 

2. Döhle bodies represent the dilated endoplasmic reticulum. They appear as blue colored inclusions inside neutrophils. These inclusions may be seen in conditions such as:

  • Sepsis
  • Severe inflammatory disorders like Kawasaki disease
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes

 

3. Flame cells: They are plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm, in the peripheral areas of the cell, due to the accumulation of immunoglobulin. 

 

4. Auer rods are azurophilic needle-like granules seen in the cytoplasm of the myeloblasts. Auer rods are usually seen in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

questions.text:
For the detection of Diabetes Mellitus in population over 40 but less than 60, two screening tests are performed together irrespective of the result of each other. This results in:

A. Decreased Specificity for detecting DM

B. Increased Sensitivity for detecting DM

C. Increased Negative predictive Value

D. Increased Specificity for detecting DM

E. Decreased Sensitivity for detecting DM

choices.text: A, B and C are correct

questions.solution:
Here, the screening tests used in parallel, i.e. the second test is independently performed regardless of what the first test result is. And, both are done at the same time.

Screening tests used in the series: where the result of the first test determines whether to run the second test or not.

  Tests in Series Tests in parallel
Combined sensitivity Decreases Increases
Combined specificity Increases Decreases
Combined PPV Increases Decreases
Combined NPV Decreases Increases

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool.

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin
Methanol, Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet
Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

questions.solution:
Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red-stained oocysts, suggestive of modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

The modified Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) method is used for staining cryptosporidium and isospora species. Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents.

The reagents used in modified ZN stain include:

  • Absolute methanol for fixation
  • Kinyoun’s Carbol fuchsin - Primary stain
  • Acid alcohol - Decolourising agent
  • Methylene blue or Malachite green - Counterstain

questions.text: Which of the following does not classify as locally advanced breast cancer?
questions.solution:
A breast tumor of size > 5 cm (not 4 cm) is classified as locally advanced breast carcinoma (LABC). 

Invasive breast carcinoma is of 3 types:

  1. Early breast carcinoma (EBC) - TNM combination of T1 to T2, N0 to N1, and M0
  2. Locally advanced breast carcinoma (LABC) - T4N0M0, T3N1M0, TanyN2-3M0
  3. Advanced breast carcinoma (ABC) - TanyNanyM1

Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) includes:

  1. Breast tumors more than 5 cm in diameter 
  2. Cancers that involve the skin or the underlying muscles of the chest (T4 of TNM staging)
  3. Cancers that involve multiple local lymph nodes (axillary or sub clavicular) 
  4. Inflammatory breast cancer - a rapidly growing type of cancer that makes the breast appear red and swollen

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to _________

choices.text: Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.solution:
Golgi tendon organ sense changes in muscle tension.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension in a contracted muscle is significantly elevated, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text: Propranolol is drug of choice for:
questions.solution:
Propranolol is the drug of choice in the management of infantile hemangioma complicated by ulceration or in symptomatic patients. 

It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis and inhibition of angiogenesis.

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The patient developed pyruvate carboxylase enzyme deficiency.
  • Biotin serves as co-enzyme for the synthesis of several carboxylase enzymes such as:
    • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase
    • Pyruvate carboxylase
    • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
    • Methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase
  • Individuals who eat an excess of uncooked egg-white, develops biotin deficiency and as a result deficiency of the carboxylase enzymes. This is because, a protein called, avidin present in the egg-white bind to biotin in the diet, and makes biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption.

questions.text: Consider the following statements regarding P falciparum. Which are True/False?
questions.solution:
Statements a and b are false as P. falciparum is resistant to chloroquine in India. 

Statement c is true, as quinine combined with doxycycline or clindamycin is effective in the treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum.

Statements d is true, as Artemisinin-based drugs such as artesunate, artemether, and dihydroartemisinin are used in the treatment of malaria. The combination of artemether and lumefantrine is effective against uncomplicated P.falciparum.

Statement e is true, as artemisinin-based drugs are short-acting, and hence they are always combined with other drugs and not given as monotherapy.

questions.text: Mark True or False regarding Fractures shaft of femur:
questions.solution:
1.  More common in elderly - False

High-velocity injuries causing shaft of femur fractures are more common in the younger population

 

2. Easily managed with gallows traction in elderly - False

Gallows traction can be tried in children <2years. Not in the elderly.

In Gallow's traction, the legs of a child are tied to an overhead beam. The hips are kept a little raised from the bed so that the weight of the body provides counter-traction and the fracture is reduced. This is continued till sufficient callus forms.

 

3. Associated with pulmonary complications - True

Fat embolism and ARDS are known complications associated with the shaft of the femur fracture

 

4. Interlocking Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management - True

Closed intramedullary nail with interlocking screws is the preferred treatment of most femoral shaft fractures.

questions.text: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring ____
questions.solution:
Anatomical dead space can be measured by the single-breath N2 curve (Fowler's method).

  • Anatomical dead space is the respiratory system volume exclusive of alveoli.
  • Alveolar dead space is the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood i.e. wasted ventilation.
  • Physiological/total dead space is the sum of anatomical and alveolar dead space.
  • The equation used for the calculation of total/physiological dead space is the Bohr’s equation.

The patient takes a deep breath of O2 From mid-inspiration, then exhales steadily. The changes in the N2 concentration of expired gas during expiration are plotted.

Region I - Dead Space (DS)

From I–II is a mixture of DS and alveolar gas.

The transition from III-IV is the closing volume (CV).

End of IV - Residual Volume (RV).

Option C: Tidal volume (TV) is measured using spirometry.

Option D: Diffusion Capacity is measured using carbon monoxide diffusion capacity (DLCO).

questions.text: The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is:
questions.solution:
The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is the portal vein.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: Hormone replacement therapy is not indicated for:
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy is not indicated in coronary artery disease prophylaxis. There is currently insufficient evidence to recommend the initiation or continuation of either estrogen therapy (ET) or estrogen-progestin therapy (EPT) for the prevention of primary or secondary coronary heart disease (CHD). 

In an 18-year reevaluation of WHI (women health initiative) participants, it was found that cardiovascular, cancer, and all-cause mortality rates were essentially the same in both the hormone therapy (HT) and placebo groups.

Currently, hormone therapy (HT) is only indicated for the treatment of bothersome vasomotor symptoms (VMS) and genitourinary symptoms, prevention of osteoporosis, and treatment of hypoestrogenism caused by hypogonadism, surgical menopause, or premature ovarian insufficiency. 

Estrogen should not be used in women with the following conditions: 

  • undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • active or prior stroke, myocardial infarction, or transient ischemic attack (TIA)
  • known thrombophilia, liver dysfunction, or disease
  • untreated hypertension
  • known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • known or suspected pregnancy

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

Newer researches and their observations reveal that a few women need prophylactic and therapeutic HRT, but 70–85% of women remain healthy and need only good nutrition and a healthy lifestyle.

questions.text: Berry aneurysm occurs due to:

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN

questions.solution:
As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome and the arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base of the neck. The media thins and connective tissue replaces smooth-muscle cells. The site of rupture is most often the dome. Here the wall thins, and the tear that allows bleeding is usually ≤0.5 mm long. 

Risk of rupture is higher if:

  • Aneurysm >7 mm in diameter
  • Aneurysm at the top of the basilar artery 
  • Aneurysm at the origin of the posterior communicating artery

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: An Intraocular lens was placed uneventfully in a young patient during cataract surgery. What should be done then?
questions.solution:
Uneventful intraocular lens placement, is not an indication for replacing the IOL. 

An IOL replacement (IOL exchange) may be done under the following conditions:

  • Incorrect IOL placed
  • Posterior or anterior dislocation of IOL
  • Hyphema
  • Asymmetrical Haptic Placement
  • Sunset Syndrome
  • Lens-Bag Decentration

Option C: In the event that secondary catarct develops, it is treated by surgical or laser (Nd:YaG) posterior capsulotomy.

Option D: Presbyopia is a disorder of accomdation seen in old age. It is usually corrected by prescription unifocal or Bifocal or multifocal glasses or contact lenses.

questions.text: The correct statement regarding the physiological changes in the respiratory system in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Functional residual capacity (FRC) decreases by 20 to 30 percent (400 to 700 mL) during pregnancy. 

FRC = Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) + Residual Volume (RV). ERV decreases by 15 to 20 percent (200 to 300 mL). RV decreases by 20 to 25 percent (200 to 400 mL).

FRC and RV decline due to diaphragm elevation. Significant reductions occur by the sixth month with a progressive decline across pregnancy.

The increased minute ventilation during pregnancy is influenced by various factors. These include the stimulatory action of progesterone, reduced expiratory reserve volume, and compensatory respiratory alkalosis. Total lung capacity (FRC + IC) decreases in pregnancy. 

Anatomical changes such as the elevation of the diaphragm, an increase in the subcostal angle, and an expansion of the transverse diameter of the thoracic cage are seen.

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such reactions can be prevented by using leukoreduced RBCs.
Removal of leukocytes from the blood is called leukoreduction. It is done before storage to prevent cytokine formation.
FNHTR may occur due to the following:
  • Sensitization to the WBC antigens by previous blood transfusions or pregnancy
  • Cytokines produced by the donor leukocytes during storage
  • Bacterial contamination

Note: Luspatercept is an erythroid maturation agent, a receptor fusion protein consisting of a modified extracellular domain of human activin receptor type-2B linked to the human Ig-G1 Fc domain. The drug was recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of transfusion-dependent thalassemia.

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?

choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
The compound has three ionisable side chains
The compound has one ionisable group

questions.solution:
The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B, which corresponds to the pK1 and pK2 of the compound.

Other options:

  • The points A and B represent the pKa of carboxyl and amino groups respectively.
  • The amino acid has no ionizable side chains as the graph shows only two pKas.
  • The amino acid has two ionizable groups: an amino group and a carboxyl group.

The above graph resembles the titration curve of the amino acid glycine.

Titration curve of Glycine:

The titration is completed at a pH of 12, where the glycine predominantly exists in the form of H2N - CH2 - COO-.

pK1 and pK2 correspond to the point where the buffering capacity is maximum.

Characteristics of the titration curve:

  • Buffering capacity is referred to as the ability of the aminoacid to resist the change in pH due to the addition of acid (H+) or base (OH- equivalents), by accepting or losing the protons respectively.
  • An ionizable group refers to the group which can either lose or accept a proton and becomes negatively charged or positively charged ion respectively.
  • During the titration, the buffering capacity of the compound reaches its maximum, at points where the pKa of the ionizable groups is reached.
  • Each of these pKa are labeled as pK1, pK2, pK3, etc.
  • The presence of two pKas indicates that the compound has two ionizable groups. Ex. Glycine.
  • The presence of three or more pKas indicates the presence of side chains on the amino acid, with additional ionizable groups.
  • Ex. histidine has three ionizable groups, an amino group, an imidazole group (on the side chain), and a carboxyl group. The pKas of these groups respectively correspond to the pK1, pK2, pK3 of the titration curve of histidine.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of melancholia?

choices.text: Profound feelings of guilt over trivial events

questions.solution:
Sleep-onset insomnia is a characteristic feature of anxiety disorder, not melancholia.

Melancholia is one of the oldest terms used in psychiatry, to describe the dark mood of depression. It is still used to refer to a state of depression characterized by:

  • Severe anhedonia
  • Early morning awakening (terminal insomnia)
  • Weight loss
  • Profound feelings of guilt (often over trivial events)

Melancholia is sometimes referred to as "endogenous depression" or depression that arises in the absence of external life stressors or precipitants.

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic that also acts as an anxiolytic and produces adverse effects like sedation, dry mouth, and hypotension. All of these actions are due to antagonism of which receptors.

a. D1, D2, and 5HT2

b. M1, M2 and A1, A2

c. GABA and beta receptors

d. H1

choices.text: a, b and d are correct
a, b, c and d are correct

questions.solution:
options a, b, and d are correct.
 
Chlorpromazineacts on the following receptors:
  • Dopamine receptors(D2>D1) antagonism is responsible for the antipsychotic action.
  • 5-HT2 receptors antagonism, which accounts for the anxiolytic, antidepressive and antiaggressive properties.
  • H1 receptor blockade causes sedation and weight gain.
  • Antimuscarinic action due to blockade of M1and M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptors causes side effects such as dry mouth, blurred vision, obstipation, difficulty/inability to urinate, sinus tachycardia, ECG-changes and loss of memory.
  • Alpha1/alpha2-receptors antagonism may cause hypotension and reflex tachycardia.

questions.text:
Choose the appropriate option with respect to the following image
  1. The mosquito exhibits a hunch back, when at rest
  2. This is the only mosquito which has no siphon tube.
  3. It is also called as ‘Tiger mosquito’
  4. It is also called as ‘Nuisance mosquito’.

choices.text: a, b and c are correct

questions.solution:
The image given shows Aedes mosquito.

  • They do not fly over long distances, usually less than 100 metres(110 yards).
  • The eggs are laid singly and are Cigar-shaped.
  • Larvae are suspended with head downwards at an angle to the water surface, siphon tube is present, No palmate hairs.
  • Adults when at rest, exhibit hunch back, wings are unspotted.
  • They are referred to as ‘Tiger mosquito’ due to the stripes or bands on the legs.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially?
questions.solution:
The above image shows penetrating injury by a metallic fish-hook.

In cases of penetrating injuries, the foreign body is removed only after ascerting it's location through a CT scan.

Hence, Removal of the foreign body is not done initially in these injuries. It is surgically explored & repaired under OT settings.

Management of penetrating injuries of the eye include:

  • Primary survey (Option D) of the patient and the wound 
  • Visual acuity assesment (Option B) in both normal and injured eye 
  • A CT scan is performed to localize the foreign body and detect any intaorbital or intracranial extensions.
  • MRI is contraindicated for metallic foreign bodies.
  • Prophylactic intravitreal antibiotics (option C) are prescribed

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease.

It is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder characterized by central nervous system dysmyelination.

The proteolipid protein gene (PLP1) is affected, leading to the failure of axon myelination by oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system.

Clinical Features:

  • Nystagmus
  • Developmental delay
  • Psychomotor delay
  • Seizure
  • Stridor
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Ataxia
  • Hypotonia progressing to spasticity.

The degree of dysmyelination is correlated with the severity of the clinical manifestations.

Genetic analysis can confirm the diagnosis. MRI shows a lack of myelination and MR spectroscopy reveals aberrant N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) and choline concentrations that reflect axonal and myelination abnormalities.

Unlike other demyelinating leukodystrophies such as metachromatic leukodystrophy and adrenoleukodystrophy, where myelin is formed but subsequently destroyed, PMD shows a failure of myelin formation.

questions.text: Mass vaccination is most effective in which of​ the following outbreaks?
questions.solution:
Mass immunization is effective in case of an outbreak of poliomyelitis.
 
The WHO has laid down standard operating procedures to be followed for responding to a poliovirus event or outbreak.
 
In the case of detection of an event or outbreak, the WHO recommends the following step-wise approach:
  1. Notification of the disease to international health regulations (IHR) focal point at the WHO regional centre.
  2. Detailed investigation and risk assessment.
  3. Enhanced surveillance to detect ongoing person-person transmission.
  4. Vaccination response to reach every child.
 
The vaccination response includes:
  1. A rapid response (RR) vaccination campaign: This campaign is initiated with 14 days of the laboratory sequencing result and targets the immediate area of the virus isolation to rapidly stop further transmission. The target population is about 2 lakh to 5 lakh children.
  2. Supplementary immunization activities (SIA): Two high-quality large-scale SIA campaigns (SIA1and SIA2) are carried out, to ensure that >90% of children are vaccinated. These campaigns should be completed within 8 weeks of laboratory sequencing result. The target population in the large scale rounds is about 2 million children.
  3. Mop-up round or additional SIAs: If the monitoring suggests that children have been missed in certain areas, then a mop-up round of immunization is done.
 
The target age group for immunization under SIAs is children less than five years of age. If there is evidence of virus circulation among older age groups, then the target age group can be expanded to 10 or 15 years or even to the whole population depending on the local context.
 
Other options:
Options a: In case of a cholera outbreak, the mainstay of response includes health education on the role of hygiene, rehydration therapy, and sanitation measures.
Option b: The mainstay of typhoid control in case of an outbreak includes health education, water quality and sanitation improvement, and training of health professionals in diagnosis and treatment. Although WHO recommends immunization as a complementary method to the above measures, there is insufficient data to ascertain the effectiveness of vaccination in case of a typhoid outbreak.
Option d: In case of measles outbreak, the control measures include isolation for seven days after the onset of rash and immunization of the contacts within 2 days of exposure.

questions.text: True/False regarding AFP surveillance:
questions.solution:
Statements a, and b are false, while all other statements are true.
 
Acute flaccid paralysis(AFP)surveillance:
There are fours steps under AFP surveillance:
 
  1. Finding and reporting children with AFP: 
    • The staff in all health facilities should report every case of AFPin any child less than 15 years of age.
    • The surveillance system of the country should be able to detect at least one case of AFP for every 1,00,000 children under 15 years of age, even in the absence of polio.
 
  1. Transporting stool samples for analysis:
    • All children with AFP should be tested for wild poliovirus.
    • The faecal samples are used to test for polio.
    • The specimens should be collected within the first two weeks after onset of paralysis since the highest concentration of the poliovirus is found during this period.
    • Two specimens taken at 24-48 hours apart are required.
    • The specimens are stored at 4-8°C and the specimens should reach the laboratory within 72 hours of collection.
 
  1. Isolating poliovirus:
    • Isolation of the virus followed by distinguishing between wild and vaccine-related poliovirus.
    • If wild type is isolated, then the virologists identify which of the two surviving types is involved.
 
  1. Mapping the virus:
    • If the wild type of virus is found, the genetic makeup of the virus is further studied and is compared with the reference bank of known polioviruses to know about the geographical origin of the virus.
    • Once the geographical area is identified, the source of importation virus can be known. Immunization strategies can be determined accordingly.

 

Completeness of follow-up is indicated if at least 80% of the cases have a follow-up examination for residual paralysis at 60 days after the onset of paralysis.

questions.text: A young boy with a history of frequent nosebleeds and unilateral nasal blockage. CT scan shows Holman- Miller sign. It also shows the presence of a mass in the nasopharynx that extends into and occupies the pterygopalatine fossa. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture suggests that of stage IIB nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgery is the mainstay of treatment of angiofibroma for stage I and stage II tumors.

Radiotherapy is indicated in stage III where there is an intracranial extension or when the tumor is unresectable.

Chemotherapy can be used for very aggressive resurrect tumors and residual lesions.

Stages of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharyngeal vault
IB Extension into ≥ 1 sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of orbital bones
IIC Infratemporal fossa with or without cheek or posterior to pterygoid plates
IIIA Erosion of skull base-minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base-extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Hormonal therapy was used in the past, but not anymore.

Recurrent angiofibroma have also been treated by Intensity-modulated radiotherapy—a newer mode of treatment.

questions.text: Acute inflammatory response is not seen in:
questions.solution:
An inflammatory response is not seen in apoptosis. In this process, the cell membrane remains intact. Hence, there is no leakage of cell contents and no surrounding inflammation.
 
On the other hand, other forms of cell death including necrosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis involve the disintegration of the cell membrane. This causes the cell contents to leak out of the cell leading to an acute inflammatory response.

Assertion is false, but the Reasons is true
Both Assertion and Reasons are false

questions.solution:
The wide availability, the fast acquisition and reporting times and the high accuracy make MDCT the imaging method of choice for the diagnosis of aortic dissection.

TEE can be performed in unstable patients and has excellent sensitivity for the aortic dissection confirmation (85–90%). However, operator-dependency reduces its specificity in the ‘blind areas’ of the distal ascending aorta and the aortic arch. Moreover, TOE cannot assess abdominal aorta and its visceral branches which may be involved in Distal /descending aortic dissections. 

Aortic dissection is the most common non-traumatic acute aortic emergency

Aortic dissection is initiated by an intimal tear that allows blood to penetrate into the medial layer, producing a false lumen between the inner two-thirds and outer one-third of media. The true lumen is separated from the false lumen by an intimomedial flap. 

The image is of an aortic dissection, showing an intimal flap, a double lumen. Arrows indicate intimal flap.

The Stanford classification is used to separate aortic dissections into those that need surgical repair, and those that usually require only medical management. The Stanford classification divides dissections by the most proximal involvement:

  • Type A: affects ascending aorta and arch:
    • Requires urgent surgical management
    • May result in:
      • Coronary artery occlusion
      • Aortic incompetence
      • Rupture into the pericardial sac with resulting cardiac tamponade
    • Type B: begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels:
      • Dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery
      • Medical management with blood pressure control

The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:

  • Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta (= Stanford A)
  • Type II: involves ascending aorta only (= Stanford A)
  • Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery (= Stanford B)

questions.text: Mark the following statements as True/False regarding a patient that presents with right-sided hemiparesis and aphasia for 1 hour.
questions.solution:
1. Tenectplase is not started if CT scan normal- False
In fact, a normal-appearing CT is a requirement for starting rtPA as the purpose of CT is to rule out a hemorrhage.

2. Tenecteplase is not started before MRI if CT scan normal - False
MRI is not be advised in the acute setting as it would cause unnecessary delay in initiating thrombolysis. In a patient of acute stroke, that has presented in the window period the imaging modality used is CT and the reason is to rule out hemorrhage. 

3. rTPA can be given when BP>150/80 - True

Contraindication to the administration of rtPA is a BP>185/110mmHg. So, the patient can be administered rtPA.

4. Q. rTPA can be given in a patient taking warfarin with INR 1.4 - True

rtPA can be safely administered in acute ischemic stroke patients that are taking warfarin when the INR is ≤1.7 without any increased risk of symptomatic ICH. 

 

Administration of rtPA

  • IV access with two peripheral IV lines (avoid arterial or central line placement)
  • Review eligibility for rtPA
  • Administer 0.9 mg/kg IV (maximum 90 mg) IV  ( 0.6 mg/kg is commonly used in Asia) -  10% as bolus followed by the remainder of total dose over 1 hour
  • Frequent cuff blood pressure monitoring
  • No other antithrombotic treatment for 24 h
  • If there is a decline in neurologic status or uncontrolled blood pressure, stop the infusion, give cryoprecipitate, and reimage brain emergently
  • Avoid urethral catheterization for ≥2 h

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: Which of the following best describes paradoxical suicide?

choices.text: Suicide occuring at the time when the patient starts to recover
Suicide after taking low dose of drug

questions.solution:
Paradoxical suicide is defined as suicide which occurs when the patient begins to recover from the depression  
  • This is because, when the patient is in depression, though he/she has the suicidal thoughts cannot act on it due to lack of energy.
  • As the patient begins to recover from depression, patients gain energy to put their suicidal thoughts into action.
It is called paradoxical, as one might expect that the risk of suicide reduces as the patient starts to recover, but on contrary to that, the risk of suicide is increased during the recovery phase.

questions.text: Mark the following statements true or false about the thyroglossal cyst.

choices.text: Thyroglossal duct obliterates by 18th week of IUL

questions.solution:
A Thyroglossal Cyst is a Congenital Midline Neck Swelling that typically presents during childhood. It is lined by pseudostratified Columnar and Squamous epithelium with 20% of cysts having Heterotropic Thyroid Tissue. It can be differentiated from other midline neck swellings by the following features: 

  • It can be moved sideways but not vertically.
  • Moves with both deglutition and protrusion of the tongue.

 

Normally, the thyroglossal duct lumen starts to obliterate during the fifth week of gestation and completely disappears by 8th week.

 

The Cyst can occur anywhere along the course of the duct, although the most common site for a Thyroglossal Cyst is Infrahyoid. 

  • Infrahyoid - the most common site 
  • Region of Thyroid Cartilages
  • Suprahyoid
  • Floor of mouth
  • Beneath Foramen Caecum

Surgical management of a thyroglossal cyst is via a Sistrunk procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hemostatic agent?
questions.solution:
Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. 
 
Topical hemostatic agents used in practice include:
  • Hemostatic field dressings
  • Surgical hemostatic agents

1. The hemostatic field dressings are the granular and gauze-based agents which are used to facilitate coagulation and hemostasis. The active ingredients used in various hemostatic field dressings are kaolin, mineral zeolite, and chitosan.

 
Mechanism of action
Advantage
Disadvantage
Kaolin
Cation based activation of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade
It is non-granular compound. Hence, it does not leave any residue upon removal of the dressing
Clots may be disrupted upon removal. It is less effective in functional or dilutional coagulopathies.
Mineral zeolite
Adsorbs the water, thereby increasing the concentration of the clotting factors, platelets, RBCs.
It is available in two forms:
 
Granular zeolite is effective for pouring into low-flow wounds.
 
The mesh-embedded product is useful in high flow wounds.
The chemical reaction which causes adsorption of water is an exothermic reaction. This causes local tissue damage. The granules may be difficult to be removed.
Chetosan
Poly-N-acetylglucosamine is commonly known as chitin. The deacetylated form of chitin is called chitosan. It has mucoadhesive properties which causes the dressing to adhere to the tissues. It induces vasospasm and attracts RBCs and platelets to the site of bleeding.
It has antimicrobial properties. It can be easily applied and has a long shelf-life.
As the dressing material adheres to the tissues, it may cause disruption of the clots upon removal.

 

2. The surgical hemostatic agents are further divided into the following groups based on the nature of the agent:

 
  • Caustic agents: They act by causing local tissue destruction, which leads to protein coagulation and precipitation. This further leads to thrombus formation and sealing of the small blood vessels. The agents include Monsel solution (a20% ferric nitrate solution), silver nitrate, and aluminum chloride.
 
  • Biological physical agents: They act by promoting platelet activation and formation of three-dimensional matrix for the formation of clots. These agents are used in several operations including neurosurgical, orthopedic, thoracic, abdominal, and vascular procedures. The agents include gelatin, oxidized cellulose, and microfibrillar collagen.
 
  • Physiologic agents: These agents activate a specific step of the coagulation cascade and promotes the clot formation. These agents include thrombin and fibrin glue/sealant.
 
  • Combination or polymer agents: These agents include several different combinations of the above agents and various synthetic hemostatic agents. Examples include gelatin-thrombin agent, polyethylene glycol hydrogel, and glutaraldehyde cross-linked albumin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol in large doses can result in hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.

Option A: Tachycardia due to reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on β2 receptors and direct effect on cardiac β1 receptors (β2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations) 

Option B: Tolerance occurs due to desensitization on long-term use 

Option C: Hypokalemia due to direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions

questions.solution:
The correct answer is a-True, b-True, c-True, d-False

questions.text:
Theme and Focus: Seizures

Answer option list:

A. IV phenobarbitone

B. Rectal diazepam

C. Intraosseous midazolam

D. Phenytoin IV

E. Nasal carbamazepine

F. Oral valproate

Lead in Question: A one and a half-year-old baby comes to OPD with a generalized convulsive episode which lasts for 45 min. On duty Senior Resident asked junior resident to start an IV line and left
questions.solution:
The baby presented with convulsive episodes lasting for 45 mins (>5 mins), which is suggestive of status epilepticus, which is a medical emergency and needs to be managed immediately.

The initial treatment usually involves intravenous diazepam, lorazepam, or midazolam. If the status does not improve the treatment is followed by phenytoin/fosphenytoin and phenobarbital, then valproate and levetiracetam.

In Scenario 1: If the IV line is not accessible, buccal or intranasal midazolam, intranasal lorazepam, or rectal diazepam.

In scenario 2: An initial IV treatment with diazepam was provided, but the patient has not improved. So, the next step is to administer a loading dose of IV phenytoin.

questions.text: Regarding ASHA, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Preparation of malaria slides is the responsibility of health worker male (HWM), not ASHA.
 
Roles and responsibilities of ASHA:
 
A. Health education:  The ASHA provides information and awareness to the community regarding nutrition, basic sanitation and hygienic practices, healthy living and working conditions, and timely utilization of health and family welfare services.
 
 
B. Maternal and child health:
  1. Facilitate utilization of health services such as immunization, antenatal and postnatal checkup and supplementary nutrition, sanitation and other services provided by the government.
  2. Provide counseling to women on birth preparedness, safe delivery, breastfeeding and complementary feeding, immunization, contraception, and prevention of common infections.
  3. Escort/accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment or admission to the nearest health center.
  4. Upon graded training, provide newborn care and management of common childhood illnesses.
 
C. Primary care:
  1. Provide primary care for minor ailments like diarrhea and fever and provide first aid for injuries.
  2. Provide DOTS under RNTCP.
  3. Depot holder of essential provisions such as oral rehydration therapy, iron and folic acid tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral pills, condoms, etc.
 
D. Sanitation:
  1. Work with village health and sanitation committee to create a comprehensive village health plan.
  2. Promote the construction of household toilets under total sanitation campaign
 
E. Notification: ASHA will inform births, deaths, and any disease outbreaks to the sub-center or PHC.

questions.text: A study was done to assess the risk factors for breast cancer in 100 females from urban cities. A statistical group and analysis are shown below. The values indicate the odds ratio and the 95% confidence interval. How many risk factors may be ascertained from the statistical analysis of the research?
questions.solution:
Among the factors shown in the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche, BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant. Hence these 3 factors can be ascertained as risk factors.
 
High socioeconomic status is not a risk factor. Even though there is a positive association, it is not statistically significant. Any association that has a 95% confidence interval range that includes the value of 1.0 is considered to be non-significant. The value of 1.0 in the range means that the two factors may co-exist together but one is not causing the other to happen.
 
Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of association between the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below:
  • OR > 1 indicates a positive association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidence limits are also >1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertained as a risk factor.
  • OR = 1indicates no association. Irrespective of the odds ratio, if the lower limit of 95% CI is <1 and the upper limit of 95% CI >1, the OR is non-significant and cannot be ascertained either as a protective or a risk factor.
  • OR < 1 indicates a negative association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidence limits are also <1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertained as a protective factor. 
Interpretation of the individual factors given in the question:
