questions.text: Which of the following hormones is exclusively secreted by adrenal gland but not by the ovaries of females?
questions.solution:
DHEAS is exclusively secreted from the adrenals but not by ovaries because ovaries lack the enzyme dehydroepiandrosterone-sulphotransferase needed to form DHEAS. 

90% of DHEA is synthesised by the adrenals and 10% comes from the ovaries.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had painful sores in the mouth with a rash over the hands along with fever. Which of these is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of fever, along with painful sores in the mouth and small, tense vescicles with surrounding erythema on the palms and soles in a child point towards the diagnosis of hand-foot-mouth disease. The most common cause of which worldwide is coxackievirus A16. 

Spread is by droplets or faecal contamination and the incubation period is 7 days. The fever is generally mild, and is followed by the appearance of lesions. The characteristic lesions are slightly oval, with a grey blister roof and a narrow rim of erythema. The oral lesions are aphthoid and are less painful than aphthous ulcers.

Only symptomatic treatment is given. The lesions generally disappear in 7 - 10 days.

questions.text: A patient with fever and joint pain developed pigmentation on the nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of fever and joint pain and the image showing hyperpigmented macules on nose (chik sign) is suggestive of Chikungunya.

Post-chikungunya pigmentation (PCP) most commonly affects the nose and cheeks. It often appears as the fever subsides and may persist for about 3-6 months.

PCP mimics melasma and may be misdiagnosed if proper history is not taken.

Another close differential is fixed drug eruptions (FDE). FDE is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by well-defined brown, hyperpigmented plaques that may follow vesiculobullous lesions. They occur on lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation.They usually present 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure and recur at the same location on re-exposure. NSAIDs, Paracetamol and Co‐trimoxazole are the most common drugs causing FDE.

The image below shows FDE on upper lip area:

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?
questions.solution:
Elevated levels of very long chain polyenoic acids have been found in the brains of patients with Zellweger syndrome.

Zellweger syndrome:

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome: Impaired neuronal migration and myelination, hepatomegaly, renal cysts
  • Reduction or absence of functional peroxisomes in tissues.
  • Accumulation of very long chain polyenoic acids in the brain.
  • Severe neurological symptoms.
  • Most patients die within the 1st year of life

questions.text:
A study was conducted to assess the effect of an intervention for certain disease. The p values for two similar studies A and B with 95% confidence limits, was found to be 0.02 and 0.001 respectively using interventions "X" and "Y" with a control group. Based on preliminary analysis, the result may be interpreted as:

A) Both studies A and B are significant

B) Study A is more significant than study B

C) Study B is more precise than study A

D) Study A is more precise than study B

choices.text: If A, B and C are correct
If A and C are correct
If B and D are correct
If all (A, B, C and D) are correct

questions.solution:
Statements A and C are correct.

 

The p-value of study A with intervention X at 95% confidence interval is 0.02.

The p-value of study B with intervention Y at 95% confidence interval is 0.001

 

The probability (p) values of both the studies are less than 0.05 (level of significance - α(alpha)). Therefore, both studies A, and B are significant, thus, rejecting the null hypothesis.

 

However, study B has a lower p-value compared to study A, which suggests that the study B with intervention Y is more significant and precise than study A with intervention X.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text:
Theme and Focus: Infertility and Tubal Diseases Lead-in question: For each case below, choose the single most appropriate diagnosis from the above option list.

Answer option list:

A. Tuboovarian mass

B. PCOS

C. Ovarian cyst

D. Endometeriosis

E. Endometrial polyp

F. Sumbumucosal fibroid
questions.solution:
In scenario 1:

The image shows Powder burn spots over pelvic viscera, in a woman with complaints of abdominal pain, who has lateral forniceal tenderness on the vaginal examination. This is suggestive of pelvic endometriosis.

  • Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called "powder burns"/"gunshot appearance" seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas.
  • Fibrosis and scarring in the peritoneum surrounding the implants is also a typical finding which is known as "Allen Masters syndrome".
  • Other subtle appearances are red flame-shaped areas, red polypoid areas, yellow-brown patches, white peritoneal areas, circular peritoneal defects or subovarian adhesions.
  • These lesions are thought to be more active than the “powder burn” areas.

 

 In scenario 2:

An obese woman with irregular periods, showing the string of pearls sign of the ovary in the ultrasound is suggestive of PCOS. The string of pearls is thought to represent the abnormal accumulation of multiple immature follicles (<5mm). 

Other features of PCOS include:

  • Hypertension

  • Virilizing signs

  • Acanthosis nigricans

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Central dogma says DNA is transcribed into RNA which is subsequently translated into proteins.
Reason (R): Retrovirus has reverse transcriptase of central dogma where RNA is first converted into DNA which is then transcribed to RNA, which is subsequently translated into proteins.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is independently true, but the Reason is independently  false
Assertion is independently  false, but the Reason is independently true
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false

questions.solution:
Both the statements are independently true. The assertion is about the central dogma of molecular biology, while the reason is an extension to the original central dogma theory. 
 
The central dogma states that genetic information flows through three major pathways:
  1. Replication: Copying of the parental DNA to the daughter DNA molecules, both having the same nucleotide sequence.
  2. Transcription: Information on a part of the genetic sequence in the DNA is copied to RNA.
  3. Translation: Information in the mRNA is translated on the ribosomes, to a polypeptide chain, leading to the synthesis of a sequence of amino acids and formation of the protein.
 
 
Extension of central dogma theory
The extension of central dogma theory, in addition, includes, reverse transcription and RNA replication seen in some viruses.
  • Some viruses such as retroviruses have an enzyme RNA-dependant-DNA polymerase that synthesises DNA from the RNA. Since it occurs in reverse to the process of transcription, the enzyme is called reverse transcriptase.
  • some viruses  with negative-sense RNA genome such as orthomyxoviruses and rhabdoviruses have an RNA dependant RNA polymerase enzyme, which is responsible for RNA replication.

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin is elevated in a case of chronic allergy?
questions.solution:
IgE is elevated in cases of chronic allergy.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: Type of mutation seen in sickle cell anemia:
questions.solution:
Point mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia.
  • Sickle cell anemia is caused by the mutation of a single base in the β-globin gene, where adenine is replaced with thymine in the sixth codon of the DNA sequence. 
  • This leads to change from GAG in the normal gene to GTG in the sickle cell gene, leading to a change in mRNA sequence from GAG to GUG.
  • As a result, the mutant gene now codes for valine instead of glutamic acid.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Atheromatous plaques are associated with dystrophic calcification. This is seen in the presence of normal calcium levels in the serum.

The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia.

Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type. Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis.

questions.text: The pH of gastric acid is 1-2 and pH of intestine is 6. PKa of weak acids like paracetamol is 9.5, and phenobarbitone is 7.2 and weak base diazepam is 3.3. Which of the following statements are true/false?
questions.solution:
Statements a, c, and d are true.

The absorption of a drug depends on whether it is in non-ionized form or ionized form. A weak acid or base remains in the non-ionized form in acidic and basic medium respectively and ionizes in the media vice versa.

A drug is absorbed easily in its non-ionized form. 

Absorption of weak acids:

  • Drugs which are weak acids like paracetamol and phenobarbital are in non-ionized form and easily absorbed in stomach.
  • However, the surface area for absorption in the stomach is less, while that of the small intestine is more.
  • As the weak acids reach the small intestine, they gets ionized.
  • Despite being in the ionized form, the maximum absorption of weak acids occurs in the small intestine, due to its large surface area.

Absorption of weak bases:

  • Weak bases like diazepam are in ionized form in the stomach and are not absorbed.
  • As they reach the small intestine, they become non-ionized and are absorbed.

Large intestine does not have any villi and has less surface area than the small intestine. However, some drugs are targeted for absorption in the large intestine.

Example: Sulfasalazine used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease, is absorbed in the colon. The sulfasalazine has azo linkages which prevent its absorption in the stomach and small intestine. The colonic bacterial azoreductases break these linkages for local effect.

The factors which increase gastric emptying, accelerate drug absorption as drug rapidly reaches the small intestine.

On the other hand, the drugs which decrease the transit time in the small intestine, like drugs causing diarrhea, decreases the absorption of other drugs.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination, he has fever with fontanelle bulging and the child was lethargic. The most probable cause is:
questions.solution:
The clinical features of poor feeding, fever, seizures (abnormal lower limb twitching), bulging fontanelle (due to raised ICP), and lethargy are all suggestive of meningitis.

Febrile seizures (Option A) are diagnosed in the absence of any other features suggestive of CNS infection. 

Pseudotumor cerebri (Option C) is rarely seen under the age of 10 years. There is an association with obesity, female gender, pregnancy, and drugs such as tetracycline, vitamin A, and retinoid derivatives. It has a chronic course of illness, with papilledema being present in a majority of cases. 

Intracranial hemorrhage (Option D) will present with seizures, focal neurological deficits, altered tone, and altered consciousness. 

Bacterial meningitis may be caused due to Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, or Haemophilus influenzae type b. 

Non-specific symptoms and signs include fever, rash, lethargy, refusal to feed, vomiting, etc. Specific symptoms and signs include photophobia, nuchal rigidity, bulging of the fontanelle, and clinical signs of meningeal irritation (Kernig and Brudzinski signs), but this is not usually seen in infants. Seizures and focal neurological signs may be present.

The diagnosis of meningitis is confirmed by CSF analysis via lumbar puncture - which typically shows micro-organisms on gram stain and culture, neutrophilic pleocytosis, increased protein, and decreased glucose concentration. Blood cultures should be done in all cases of suspected meningitis. 

Acute CNS complications include seizures, increased ICP, cranial nerve palsies, stroke, cerebral or cerebellar herniation, and thrombosis of the dural venous sinuses. Subdural effusions and non-communicating hydrocephalus may develop.

questions.text: The wrong statement regarding the levator ani muscle is:
questions.solution:
Levator Ani Muscle is not attached to the pelvic brim. It takes its origin from the body of the pubis, the arcus tendinous of the levator ani (a thickened part of the obturator fascia), and the ischial spine.

  • Insertion :- The coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament.
  • Nerve supply :- The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 and the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve.
  • Supports and raises the pelvic floor.
  • Consists of the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
questions.solution:
The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as faggot cells (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).  

Since the question specifically asks about the cell, the best answer is faggot cell (not Auer rods).

Option A: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia).  

Option B: The term flaming promyelocyte refers to cells that appear to be breaking apart, taking on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding cellular matrix. 

Option C: Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear dusky or hazy and are referred to as dusky promyelocytes.

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for:
questions.solution:
The given image is of Titmus stereotest, which is done for the assesment of stereopsis (perception of depth).

  • The pictures consist of a housefly for children and circular patterns for adults.
  • The picture is held in front of the eyes of the patient at a distance of about 16 inches and the patient is asked to wear polarized glasses. 
  • If the patient's perception of the depth is normal, the housefly appears to rise above the plane, like a 3D image. If the patient is asked to pinch the wings of the housefly, he/she will try to pinch in the air, above the plane of the image.
  • If the patient's perception of depth in either eye is defective, then the image appears just like normal 2D image.

Option A: Tests for ocular deviation include

  • Cover tests
  • Prism cover test- This will tell the amount of deviation in prism dioptres.
  • Maddox rod test
  • Hirschberg corneal reflex test

The below given image shows Maddox rod test.

Option C: Test for refractive error includes

  • Retinoscopy
  • Auto refractometry

The below given image shows the findings of Retinoscopy in different refractive errors.

Option D: Tests for colour blindness include

  • Ishihara test: It is frequently used to screen for a red–green colour vision deficit. It consists of a test plate followed by 16 plates, each with a series of dots arranged to show a shape or number that the subject is asked to identify.
  • Hardy–Rand–Rittler test: It is similar to ishihara test but is used to detect all three color vision defect.
  • Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test: Is the most sensitive test for both acquired and congenital colour blindness. It consists of 85 caps of different hue that needs to be rearranged.

The below given image depicts the ishihara test.

Related Pearl: Grades of binocular vision

I - Simultaneous perception                       

  • Ability to see two dissimilar objects simultaneously

II - Fusion

  • Ability to superimpose two incomplete but similar images

III - Stereopsis

  • Ability to perceive depth

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text: On finding a congenital heart block in a fetus, which of the following conditions would you evaluate for in the mother?
questions.solution:
On finding a congenital heart block in the fetus, the mother should be evaluated for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Fetal and neonatal heart blocks occur due to myocarditis and fibrosis in the region between the AV node and the bundle of His. Congenital heart block primarily develops in fetuses of women with antibodies to the SS-A or SS-B antigens, and up to 50 percent of women with SLE test positive for these antibodies. So in pregnancies with either of these antibodies, fetal cardiac monitoring is performed between 18 and 26 weeks of gestation.

The cardiac lesion is permanent, and in most cases, a pacemaker is required. Maternal hydroxychloroquine therapy is associated with a reduced incidence of fetal heart block, particularly in women who have previously had an affected child.

Neonatal lupus erythematosus is thought to be caused by the transplacental passage of maternal antibodies. It is characterized by skin lesions known as lupus dermatitis in newborns, as well as various hematological and systemic abnormalities. In some cases, congenital heart block may also occur. Thrombocytopenia and hepatic involvement are also seen. 

The most common cutaneous finding in neonatal lupus erythematosus is an erythematous, slightly scaly eruption on the face and periorbital skin (raccoon sign/owl eye/eye mask). The eruption can be exacerbated by UV exposure. The rash improves over the first few months of life and usually resolves without scarring by 12 months of age.

Avoidance of sunlight should be advised and low‐potency topical steroids may be of benefit.

The pregnancy outcomes are best in women with:

  •  Dormant lupus activity for at least 6 months before conception
  •  No lupus nephritis manifestation in the form of proteinuria or renal dysfunction
  •  Absent anti-phospholipid syndrome or lupus anticoagulant 
  •  Superimposed preeclampsia does not develop

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Orthostatic hypotension is not a core clinical feature of Lewy body dementia (LBD) as per DSM-5.

LBD also known as dementia with Lewy bodies is the second most type of progressive dementia after Alzheimer’s disease. Protein deposits, called Lewy bodies, deposit in nerve cells in the brain region involved in thinking, memory, and movement (motor control)

Core features of LBD as per DSM-5 are fluctuating cognition, attention, alertness, recurrent visual hallucination, and Parkinsonian symptoms. Suggestive features are REM sleep behavior disorder and severe neuroleptic sensitivity.
Orthostatic hypotension, erectile dysfunction, and constipation are other features of LBD.

Treatment of LBD includes rivastigmine and donepezil which may improve cognition, and reduce hallucinosis and delusion. Pimavanserin may be used to treat psychosis.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to ________
questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin.

Hepcidin is released by the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels. It inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, iron becomes trapped within duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost as these cells are sloughed.

Note: In hereditary hemochromatosis, there will be impaired hepcidin synthesis resulting in increased iron absorption.

questions.text:
Match the following about the mechanism of vascular leakage in acute inflammation:
Column-A Column-B
1. Sunburn less than 24 hrs a. Immediate sustained
2. Thorn prick and mast release b. Delayed prolonged
3. Bacterial infection with necrosis c. Immediate transient
4. Release of VEGF in tumors d. Delayed transient
  e. Transcytosis
  f. Pinocytosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:
  1. Sunburn less than 24 hours- b) Delayed prolonged response
  2. Thorn prick and mast release- c) Immediate transient response
  3. Bacterial infection with necrosis- a) Immediate sustained response
  4. Release of VEGF in tumors - e) Transcytosis
 
The vascular leakage (increased vascular permeability) may occur in acute inflammation by several mechanisms as stated in the table below:
 
Mechanism of leakage
Type of response
Examples
Contraction of endothelial cells leading to increased inter-endothelial spaces.
Immediate transient: Response occurs immediately and is short-lived (for15-30 minutes). The response is elicited by the release of mediators such as histamine, bradykinin, and leukotrienes.
 
  • Thorn prick causing mast release and thereby release of histamine.
  • Allergic response
 
Delayed prolonged: The vascular leakage due to endothelial contraction starts after a delay of 2-12 hours and lasts for several hours to days.
  • Sunburn
  • Irradiation or ultraviolet radiation
Direct endothelial injury, causing endothelial necrosis and cell detachment.
Immediate sustained: The response starts immediately and is sustained for several hours.
  • Burns
  • Bacterial infection
Transcytosis: Stimulation of intracellular channels by VEGF causing transport of fluid and proteins
 
  • Trauma
  • Tumors

questions.text:
The correct sequential arrangement of the auditory pathway from the periphery to center:
  1. Vestibulocochlear nerve
  2. Superior olivary nucleus
  3. Medial geniculate body
  4. Cochlear nuclei
  5. Lateral lemniscus
  6. Inferior colliculus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is

  1. Vestibulocochlear nerve
  2. Cochlear Nucleus
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex

 

 

The clinical significance of the auditory pathway is illustrated by the following pearl

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of liver failure?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of liver failure is paracetamol poisoning.

The most common hepatotoxin causing chronic liver disease is alcohol.

questions.text: All of the followings are seen in GDM except:
questions.solution:
Malformations are not associated with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). Malformations occur due to the disruption of organogenesis, usually occurring in the first trimester. The abnormal glycemic status in GDM manifests only in the second trimester.

Overt diabetes (pregestational diabetes) is associated with higher rates of malformations compared to the general population. Neural tube defects (encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), transposition of great vessels (TGA), ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen.  

Caudal regression syndrome is rare, but a specific anomaly seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters. 

Other options: 

Option B:  In GDM, increased blood glucose in the mother leads to fetal hyperglycemia. This can cause polyhydramnios due to increased fetal urine production.

Option C: Fetal hyperinsulinemia causes increased hepatic glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis, accelerated lipogenesis, and augmented protein synthesis resulting in macrosomia 

Option D: Fetal hyperglycemia in GDM triggers fetal hyperinsulinemia, resulting in neonatal hypoglycemia

questions.text:
Assertion: Antibiotics are the main line of treatment in neonatal diarrhoea.
Reason: Majority of diarrhoea in noeonate are viral.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are true and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
Assertion is true, but the Reason is false
Assertion is false, but the Reasons is true
Both Assertion and Reasons are false

questions.solution:
The assertion is independently a false statement and the reason is independently a true statement. 

The most common causative agent of diarrhoea in neonates is Rotavirus. Other viruses which can cause diarrhoea include adenovirus, calicivirus, astrovirus, enterovirus.

The mainstay of treatment includes rehydration with ORS and replacement of lost fluids.

questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:
questions.solution:
The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

The costal margin, xiphoid process, and the mid-clavicular line are seen in this image. The examiner draws a laterally convex line that extends from a level below the 2nd costal cartilage (as clued in by the sternal angle) i.e., 3rd costal cartilage to about 3 spaces below i.e., the 6th costal cartilage. This line is about 1.2 cms lateral to the sternal edge. These suggest that the region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

The projection of the cardiac borders, of an average adult, onto the anterior thoracic wall forms a trapezoid.  This can be mapped out using the percussion method by looking for cardiac dullness. 

The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows:

  • Upper border: Slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium.
  • Right border: Convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1–2 cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium.
  • Inferior border or acute border: Runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac apex which is located approximately 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle.
  • Left border or obtuse border: Convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It corresponds to the left ventricle.

questions.text: The following image of a FAST scan in a trauma patient suggests:
questions.solution:
The image of FAST in a trauma patient suggests Positive FAST as there is a fluid collection in the abdominal cavity. The thin anechoic area located between the liver(on the left) and the Kidney(on the right) is a collection of fluid visualized in this RUQ Sonogram image. 

 

FAST stands for Focused assessment with sonography for trauma. It is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Technique:

  • Patient in the supine position
  • 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer
  • Following regions are scanned :
    • Subxiphoid: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

An "extended FAST or eFAST" scan may be performed: left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

 

Sequentially order of FAST is:- pericardial sac, the Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ), Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ), and pelvis.

4 ‘Ps’ are evaluated in sequence: Pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis.

 

Note:-

In Pneumoperitoneum, air is collected in the peritoneal cavity which is usually hyperechoic not anechoic and would appear white in the ultrasound image.

questions.text: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between _____.
questions.solution:
The risk of developing fetal varicella syndrome (congenital varicella syndrome) is highest when the mother develops varicella infection between 13 to 20 weeks. 

Congenital varicella syndrome occurs in 2% of infants with maternal varicella between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation and in 0.4% of infants before 13 weeks of gestation. It is rare after 20 weeks.

Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like pattern (zig-zag scarring), and limb hypoplasia (shown below). They can also present with neurological abnormalities (microcephaly, cortical atrophy, mental retardation), ophthalmic features (chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, cataract), and renal and autonomic system abnormalities (hydronephrosis, neurogenic bladder). Low birth weight is also common. 

Infants born to mothers with varicella in the period from 5 days prior to delivery up to 2 days after delivery are at high risk for severe neonatal varicella. They acquire the infection transplacentally.

Since the mother has not developed a strong antibody response, the infant lacks the protective effect of maternal anti-varicella-zoster virus (VZV) antibodies.  Therefore varicella-zoster immune globulin (VZIG) should be administered as soon as possible after birth to newborns whose mothers have varicella 5 days before and up to 2 days after the delivery. 

Since perinatally acquired varicella can be potentially life-threatening, the infant should typically be treated with intravenous acyclovir (10 mg/kg every 8 hours) when lesions appear. 

For pregnant women with uncomplicated primary varicella or herpes zoster that does not require hospitalization, the recommended treatment is oral acyclovir (800 mg five times daily for seven days).

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him?

choices.text: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.solution:
A 45 year old diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is likely to have type 2 diabetes and thus, he should undergo screening for diabetic retinopathy immediately.

Duration of diabetes is the most important risk factor for developing diabetic retinopathy, especially proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The recommendations for first fundus examination in diabetic retinopathy is:

  • Within 3-5 years of diagnosis in type 1 diabetes
  • Immediately in type 2 diabetes.

Later, the screening is continued once every year in both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes. In the event proliferative diabetic retinopathy develops, screening is done more frequently - once every 2 months.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma
